message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Adenovirus infection is known to cause blood in the urine. It can lead to hemorrhagic cystitis, which is characterized by inflammation and bleeding in the bladder. The other options are not commonly associated with hematuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the mother suggest adenovirus infection, which can cause urinary tract infections and hematuria. BK virus infection and E. coli infections can also cause urinary tract infections, but are less likely to present with hematuria. Toxin exposure is not a common cause of these symptoms in a previously healthy child.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely cause of the hematuria is adenovirus infection. Adenovirus can cause inflammation of the urinary tract and blood in the urine, and is a common cause of urinary tract infections in children. The other options are less likely to cause these symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus infection is a common cause of hemorrhagic cystitis, which presents with blood in the urine and can occur in children. The other options are less likely causes, with BK virus infection more commonly affecting immunocompromised individuals and E. coli infection causing more typical symptoms of urinary tract infection without the presence of bright-red urine with a blood clot. Toxin exposure may also cause blood in the urine, but would likely present with other symptoms as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only adenovirus infection can cause cystitis and hematuria, which can present as bright-red urine with clots. E. coli infection can cause cystitis but is less likely to cause hematuria with clots. BK virus infection and toxin exposure are not known to cause cystitis or hematuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Adenovirus infection can cause hemorrhagic cystitis, which presents with blood in the urine and discomfort with urination. E. coli infections may cause urinary tract infections but typically without blood clots.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only adenovirus infection can cause hemorrhagic cystitis, which presents as blood in the urine with clots. E. coli infection can cause urinary tract infection but is not typically associated with hematologic complications.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely cause is Adenovirus infection. E. Coli may cause a urinary tract infection, but the bright-red urine and clot suggest hematuria, which is not typical of a UTI. BK virus infection can also cause hematuria, but it is less common than Adenovirus. Toxin exposure would likely cause other symptoms besides hematuria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus infection can cause hemorrhagic cystitis, which can present as blood in urine with or without clots. The other options are not commonly associated with hemorrhagic cystitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Adenovirus infection can cause hemorrhagic cystitis, which leads to blood in the urine with an apparent blood clot. The other options do not commonly cause this symptom.
